title: Giving consumers time limits on offers make them less likely to buy
text:
Overzealous salespeople might be wasting their time giving the hard sell, according to scientists.

A study found people who were put under pressure or given less time to decide whether to buy something were more likely to walk away.

From doorstep sellers only passing through the area, to 'buy now' offers online or one-time phone offers, people are more likely to buy if they're left alone.

Having a longer period of time to make the decision increased the chance of a sale by 13 per cent, the study found.

Researchers added shoppers appear to be less motivated by panic than was once believed.

The hard sell could be a waste of time, according to scientists, because people make surprisingly rational decisions even when under tight time constraints (stock image)

‘Our results suggest that the main reason why a firm can benefit by making time-limited offers is not that consumers make less rational decisions under time pressure,’ says Professor Robert Sugden at the University of East Anglia, an author on the study.

British and Australian researchers conducted an experiment in which about 200 participants were required to buy a product.

They faced a sequence of offers with different prices, one of which was a time-limited offer.

Researchers found that increasing the period during which a time-limited offer was available from four to 12 seconds increased the chance of it being chosen by 13 per cent (stock image)

SHOPPING REALLY DOES MAKE YOU 'HAPPIER' It's the news that will strike fear into the hearts of those who pay off the family credit cards every month. Research last year found that retail therapy - far from being empty and superficial - can be an ‘effective way to minimise sadness.’ It can even help a person feel more in control of their environment, researchers claim. Generations of consumers have been urged to satisfy their desire to keep abreast of the latest fashion by simply browsing in store and window shopping. But researchers from the University of Michigan claim ‘retail therapy’ should no longer be dismissed as it could help people overcome melancholy. The study carried out three experiments to investigate whether shopping restored a sense of control in people to combat feelings of sadness. The research found that buying something was up to 40 times more effective at giving people a sense of control and they were three times happier than those who only browsed. Previous studies have shown that shoppers enjoy positive feelings when reflecting on their most recent purchase, when that shopping had been motivated by a desire to repair mood.

The researchers found that increasing the period during which a time-limited offer was available from four to 12 seconds increased the chance of it being chosen by 13 per cent.

They also discovered that people didn't choose time-limited offers to avoid the regret of missing out on the best offer, as was previously thought.

‘The main mechanism by which time-limited offers benefit retailers is not by using time constraints to impair the rationality of consumers’ decision making,’ the researchers’ paper reads.

‘Rather it is a mechanism of search deterrence – a restriction of consumers’ opportunities to compare available offers – amplified by consumers’ risk aversion.'

The research paper says a time-limited offer ‘presents a consumer with a binary decision under uncertainty’.

And the more they think about the decision, the stronger the feeling of wanting to avoid a risk becomes.

'The search-deterring effects of time-limited offers are intensified by psychological factors, particularly when consumers are not subject to high time pressure,' said Dr Mengjie Wang from the University of East Anglia.

Even when subjects were allowed only four seconds in which to accept or reject an offer, their decisions were rational and ‘remarkably sophisticated’.

The research challenges previously assumptions that consumers are prone to making less rational decisions under time pressure.

The study - which was conducted by researchers at the University of Anglia and the University of Queensland, Australia - was published in the Journal of Economic Behavior and Organization.
description: Researchers from the University of East Anglia found people were less motivated by panic than they had expected them to be, and made surprisingly rational, calculated decisions under pressure.
